newsitem.title: PORTUGAL: Portugal has not received illegal UK beef - paper.
newsitem.headline: Portugal has not received illegal UK beef - paper.

text.p: Portugal imported 673.3 tonnes of beef from Britain after the imposition of a European Union embargo on British beef exports, but the imports were legal, a Lisbon newspaper reported on Thursday.
Diario Economico said that according to figures obtained from the National Statistics Institute, Portugal imported the beef from Britain between April 1996 and March this year.

The EU banned exports of British beef and beef products in March 1996 to protect consumer health after the British government said it was possible a human form of the fatal mad cow disease, CJD, could be caught from eating infected beef.

Diario Economico quoted Pedro Ribeiro, a senior Agriculture Ministry official, as saying that beef imported by Portugal had been re-exported by British companies after arriving mainly from the U.S., Australia, New Zealand and Argentina.
It quoted Ribeiro as saying the European Commission had told Portugal that it was not on the list of nations that had broken the embargo.
Ribeiro said imports of beef from Britain were conducted by companies "authorised by the European Commission and subject to special controls."
The European Commission said on Wednesday it was considering legal action against Britain for illegal exports of unspecified quantities of British beef to European Union and other states.
EU Food Safety Commissioner Emma Bonino told Italian TV that British beef had been exported to four EU countries.
"At the present stage of the inquiry British beef was found to have been exported to Belgium, France, Spain and the Netherlands," Bonino said.
Spain told its regions to put a freeze on beef that might have been imported illegally from Britain through Belgium.
Portuguese government officials were not immediately available to comment on the Diario Economico report.
